key_insight: Combining a lightweight triangle mesh with anisotropic 3D Gaussians yields photorealistic head avatars that are both memory-efficient and fast to render on mobile devices.
problem_solved: Bridges the trade-off between fidelity, memory footprint, and rendering speed for photorealistic head avatars reconstructed from multi-view images, enabling real-time or mobile deployment.
method: Hybrid representation: a compact triangle mesh models large smooth surface regions (e.g., skin) while anisotropic 3D Gaussians capture fine detail and soft volumetric effects.
Reconstruction from multi-view images to fit both mesh and Gaussian components into a unified codec-like representation.
Optimized encoding and rendering pipeline tailored for efficient memory use and real-time rendering on mobile GPUs.
impact: Enables practitioners to deploy high-quality, real-time avatar experiences on resource-constrained devices (mobile/AR), reducing bandwidth and memory needs without sacrificing photorealism.
visual_elements: Side-by-side rendering: photorealistic output vs. mesh-only and Gaussian-only ablations

paper_title: Gaussian Pixel Codec Avatars: A Hybrid Representation for Efficient Rendering
paper_authors: Divam Gupta, Anuj Pahuja, Nemanja Bartolovic, Tomas Simon, Forrest Iandola
